definition: A ballot submitted by mail or drop box by a voter who cannot be physically present at their polling place on Election Day.
A change or addition to a constitution, law, or bill.
The official document, paper, or digital form used by voters to make their choices in an election.
A proposed law presented to a legislature for consideration.
An organized effort by a candidate or political group to win an election.
A person who seeks election to a public office.
A meeting of members of a political party to select candidates or decide on policy.
A population count conducted every ten years in the U.S. that affects representation and funding.
A person who lives in an area represented by an elected official.
The fundamental set of laws and principles that define a government's structure and powers.
A formal discussion between candidates or parties to share their views and persuade voters.
A system of government in which citizens hold the power to make decisions through voting.
A geographic area represented by a specific elected official, such as a member of Congress.
The legal requirement that the government must respect all rights owed to a person under the law.
The group of representatives who formally cast votes for President and Vice President based on state results.
A directive issued by the President that manages operations of the federal government.
A tactic used in the Senate to delay or block a vote on a bill by extending debate.
The main election where voters choose between candidates from different parties.
The practice of drawing voting district boundaries to favor one party or group.
The lower chamber of the U.S. Congress, with members serving two-year terms representing districts.
The process by which a legislative body brings charges against a government official for misconduct.
A person currently holding a political office who is running for reelection.
A voter who does not align with or register under any political party.
The power of courts to determine whether laws or actions of government are constitutional.
The act of trying to influence decisions made by government officials, often by interest groups or organizations.
The principle that the decision supported by more than half of voters or representatives wins.
An election held halfway through a president's term, where voters choose members of Congress and local officials.
The process by which a political party selects its candidate for election to public office.
Not affiliated with or influenced by any political party.
A formal promise made by an official to carry out their duties and uphold the Constitution.
An organization that raises and spends money to influence elections or legislation.
The physical location where voters go to cast their ballots on Election Day.
An election where voters choose which candidates will represent their party in the general election.
A ballot used when there is uncertainty about a voter's eligibility, counted once eligibility is confirmed.
The minimum number of members required for a legislative body to conduct business.
An election that allows voters to remove an elected official from office before their term ends.
A direct vote by citizens on a specific law or issue.
The process of signing up to be eligible to vote in an election.
A second election held when no candidate receives a majority of votes in the first round.
The upper chamber of the U.S. Congress, with two senators from each state serving six-year terms.
A state where support for major political parties is close, making it important in presidential elections.
A legal restriction on how many times a person can be elected to the same office.
A formal agreement between two or more countries, ratified by the Senate in the U.S.
The percentage of eligible voters who actually cast ballots in an election.
A decision where all members or voters are in complete agreement, with no one opposing.
The power of the President or governor to reject a bill passed by the legislature.
A form of identification some states require to verify a voter's identity at the polls.
Any action or policy that makes it harder for certain groups of people to vote.
A landmark 1965 law that outlawed racial discrimination in voting.
A court order requiring that a person under arrest be brought before a judge to determine if their detention is lawful.
Fear or hatred of foreigners, which can influence political movements and policies.
Sensational or exaggerated news reporting meant to influence public opinion or sell papers.
A belief that one side's gain in politics always means the other's loss, discouraging compromise.
